key_insight: GITIII is a lightweight, self-supervised graph transformer that infers spatial single-cell interactions and, by interpreting learned cell state–niche correlations, quantifies how neighbouring cells influence a receiver cell’s gene expression.
problem_solved: Existing spatial transcriptomics methods struggle to infer and quantify cell-to-cell influence at single-cell resolution in an interpretable and scalable way.
method: Self-supervised graph-transformer training on cell neighborhoods to learn correlations between intrinsic cell state and extrinsic niche context.
Attention-derived influence scores that attribute how much each neighbouring cell contributes to changes in a receiver cell's gene expression, enabling interpretability.
Lightweight architecture optimized for efficiency and scalability to large spatial transcriptomics datasets.
impact: GITIII gives AI/ML practitioners an interpretable, scalable tool to extract biologically meaningful spatial interaction signals, enabling downstream analyses (e.g., causal hypothesis generation, marker prioritization) and integration of attention-based influence metrics into pipelines.
visual_elements: Tissue schematic: cells as graph nodes with edges for physical neighbors, colored by cell state.
Overlay heatmap on tissue showing attention/influence weights from neighbors to a highlighted receiver cell.
Bar/violin plots of per-gene or per-cell influence scores to compare neighbour effects quantitatively.
Simplified model diagram: lightweight graph-transformer pipeline (input features → self-supervised pretraining → attention scores → influence quantification).
paper_title: Inferring spatial single-cell-level interactions through interpreting cell state and niche correlations learned by self-supervised graph transformer
paper_authors: Xiao Xiao, Le Zhang, Hongyu Zhao, Zuoheng Wang
